title: CHARACTERS USEFUL IN DETERMINING THE POSITION OF INDIVIDUAL TEETH IN THE PERMANENT CHfEEK-TOOTH SERIES OF MERYCHIPPINE HORSES

body_text.text: Cheek-teeth of fossil horses display structural characters long been recognized as of considerable value in establishi lationships of these forms and in furnishing suggestions a of the deposits in which the fossils occur. In later Cenozoic of western North America where complete skulls and skele are not always available, identification of members of the often based on single teeth.

In the study of an individual hypsodont equine tooth di frequently encountered in determining with certainty it the cheek-tooth series. Variation in the enamel pattern as by the molars and premolars makes it particularly desirab where an individual tooth belongs in the series.

The problem of identifying teeth when detached from ja the study of a large number of merychippine teeth secured fornia Institute in the Merychippus Zone of the north Coal California. The collections from this Miocene horizon proximately two thousand separate horse teeth, representin the species Merychippus californicus Merriam. While chara assist in determining the position of a tooth apply particul species, the criteria on which identification is made are ap individual teeth in a number of generic types of horses fr Cenozoic.

The problem was suggested by Dr. Chester Stock under whose supervision it was investigated. The writer wishes to express his thanks to Dr. Stock for his kindly guidance during the course of the study. The illustrations have been prepared by Mr. John L. Ridgway.

The position of a tooth in the maxillary or ramus and which its vertical axis makes with the plane of the occlusal the series governs in large measure the attitude of the surf as seen in external view. As is shown in figure 1, the plane clusal surface truncates the crown of each tooth in the series at different angle. These angles rarely vary beyond ce limits. Consequently they furnish a reliable means tion of individual permanent cheek-teeth in practic Tertiary horses can be definitely established. With an unworn tooth the measurements are taken one-third of the distance from the summit to the base of the crown. While a or more is always indicative of a molar tooth, the ratio in with the degree of wear of the crown. A tooth in which the angle has a value ly 94? and 91? can not be definitely determined as to position Summary of characters useful in determining the position of indiv The intensive study of the sexual cycle in the rhesus females of the Carnegie Colony soon gave the very definite impression that the summer months constitute the non-breeding season, when the ovulatory function is at a low ebb and the menstrual cycle as well as the behavior of the sexes to each other show more aberrant phenomena than during the more favorable, the colder, months of the year. The impression has become a certainty. It is the purpose of the present paper to present the evidence along several lines, all of which point in the same direction.

The general testimony in the literature is to the eff do not have a breeding season. In superior cheek-teeth the anteroposterior diameter is the distance across the occlusal surface from the middle of the faces of contact of the adjoining anterior and posterior teeth. This diameter does not include the anterior projection of the parastyle in advance of the principal contact plane of the tooth.
